div.p: Dhofar is a rather mountainous region located in southern Oman, on the eastern border with Yemen. Historically the region was the chief source of frankincense in the world. Dhofar has a tribal community and is home to many ancient tribes. The Dhofari dialect is quite distinct from those of the rest of Oman and Yemen.

The oldest data available for the dialect of Dhofar was gathered by the Greek-Austrian Semitist Nikolaus Rhodokanakis, whose recordings of the dialect date back to the 1904. His study on the dialect is in two volumes: Rhodokanakis (1908) is a collection of 17 narratives and 112 poems with German translation, with an appendix of adages in the dialect of the Dhofar region; and Rhodokanakis (1911) includes a glossary and a grammatical discussion of the dialect’s phonology and morphology, with some remarks on the syntax. The introduction to the second volume includes notes on the rhythmic form of the poems of the first volume.

After a long research break, Richard J. Davey investigated the dialect of the region again. Davey (2015) examines analytical genitive constructions in coastal Dhofari Arabic. Davey (2016) is a rather comprehensive grammatical study presenting the key phonological and morpho-syntactic features of Dhofar’s coastal dialect. It includes a basic lexicon and four sample texts.
Rhodokanakis (1911) has a 66-page Arabic-German glossary. The lexicon in Davey (2016) has 17 pages of lexical items from 21 categories.
